baseline_groups.claim_summary: EE reallocation rate positively predicts nominal earnings growth across markets/time, even after controlling for all other labor flows. Coefficient on xee in all-flows specification is ~0.048, meaning a 1pp higher EE rate is associated with 4.8% higher nominal earnings growth.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline coefficient 0.0476 with SE 0.0008 (classical). With cluster(mkt) SE, p=0.037 -- still significant. Strong positive result for nominal earnings.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: EE reallocation rate positively predicts real earnings growth across markets/time, controlling for all other labor flows. Coefficient on xee ~0.041, similar pattern to nominal but slightly smaller.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline coefficient 0.0406 with SE 0.0008 (classical). With cluster(mkt) SE, p=0.037 -- still significant. Strong positive result for real earnings.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: EE reallocation rate has a near-zero and statistically insignificant effect on nominal hourly wage growth in the all-flows specification. Coefficient ~0.0004, p=0.19 (classical SE). With clustered SE, p=0.94.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline coefficient 0.0004, effectively zero. Sign and significance vary across control progressions: positive and significant with fewer controls, near-zero with all flows. Paper's point is precisely this contrast with earnings.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: EE reallocation rate negatively predicts real hourly wage growth in the all-flows specification. Coefficient ~-0.0037. Sign flips relative to earnings measures and relative to sparser specifications.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline coefficient -0.0037. With cluster(mkt) SE, p=0.56 -- not significant. The negative sign in all-flows spec contrasts with positive sign in EE-only spec (0.0025). This group shows the most sensitivity to control set.

global_notes: All baseline groups match the surface definition. No changes to baseline-group assignments. All 68 specs executed successfully. The key finding pattern is confirmed: EE rate strongly predicts earnings growth (G1, G2) but has ambiguous/opposite sign for hourly wages (G3, G4) once other flows are controlled for.
